questions.question: An estate is required to file Form 1041 if it has:

options.B: Gross income of $600 or more
options.C: Gross income of $1,000 or more

questions.explanation: An estate must file Form 1041 if it has gross income of $600 or more for the tax year, or if it has a beneficiary who is a nonresident alien.
questions.tip: Estate/trust filing threshold = $600 gross income. Lower than individual thresholds.

questions.question: A trust is taxed as:

options.B: A pass-through entity similar to a partnership
options.C: A separate taxpayer with income distribution deduction
options.D: Part of the grantor's individual return

questions.explanation: A trust (other than a grantor trust) is taxed as a separate entity. It receives a distribution deduction for income distributed to beneficiaries, who then report that income. Undistributed income is taxed at trust rates.
questions.tip: Trusts = separate taxpayer. Distributed income taxed to beneficiaries; retained income taxed to trust.

questions.question: A simple trust is required to:

options.B: Distribute all income currently and make no charitable contributions
options.C: Distribute income at the trustee's discretion

questions.explanation: A simple trust: (1) must distribute all income currently, (2) cannot make distributions from corpus, and (3) cannot make charitable contributions. Any trust that does not meet all three requirements is a complex trust.
questions.tip: Simple trust = must distribute ALL income currently, NO corpus distributions, NO charity.

questions.question: An estate may elect to use:

options.B: Any fiscal year ending within 12 months of the decedent's death
options.C: Only the decedent's tax year

questions.explanation: An estate may elect to use either a calendar year or any fiscal year ending within 12 months of the decedent's death. This provides flexibility in tax planning for estate income.
questions.tip: Estates can use fiscal year (within 12 months of death). Trusts usually must use calendar year.

questions.question: What personal exemption is allowed for an estate on Form 1041?
questions.explanation: An estate receives a $600 exemption deduction. A trust that is required to distribute all income currently (simple trust) receives a $300 exemption, while other trusts (complex trusts) receive a $100 exemption.
questions.tip: Exemptions: Estate = $600, Simple trust = $300, Complex trust = $100.

questions.question: Income from a grantor trust is reported by:

options.B: The beneficiaries
options.C: The grantor

questions.explanation: A grantor trust is disregarded for income tax purposes. All income, deductions, and credits are reported directly on the grantor's individual tax return as if they still owned the assets.
questions.tip: Grantor trust = ignored for tax purposes. Grantor reports all income on their 1040.

questions.question: Distributable Net Income (DNI) serves as:

options.A: The minimum amount that must be distributed
options.B: The ceiling on the distribution deduction and the amount taxable to beneficiaries
options.C: The amount subject to estate tax

questions.explanation: DNI is a ceiling that limits both: (1) the trust's/estate's distribution deduction, and (2) the amount taxable to beneficiaries. Without DNI, income could be taxed twice or not at all.
questions.tip: DNI = cap on distribution deduction AND beneficiary income. Prevents double taxation/undertaxation.

questions.question: Which item is added back to taxable income when calculating DNI?

options.B: Capital gains allocated to corpus
options.C: Tax-exempt interest (net of allocable expenses)

questions.explanation: DNI includes tax-exempt interest (reduced by allocable expenses) because it may be distributed to beneficiaries who need to report it. Capital gains allocated to corpus are typically excluded from DNI since they are not distributed.
questions.tip: DNI includes tax-exempt interest, excludes capital gains in corpus. Adjusts for what flows to beneficiaries.

questions.question: A simple trust has DNI of $15,000 and distributes $18,000 to beneficiaries. What is the trust's distribution deduction?
questions.explanation: The distribution deduction is limited to DNI ($15,000), even though more was distributed. The excess $3,000 is a tax-free distribution of corpus to beneficiaries (no income to report on that portion).
questions.tip: Distribution deduction capped at DNI. Excess distribution = tax-free corpus to beneficiaries.

questions.question: Income in Respect of a Decedent (IRD) includes:

options.A: Capital gains on sale of inherited property
options.B: Income the decedent was entitled to but had not yet received at death
options.C: Tax-exempt bond interest

questions.explanation: IRD is income the decedent earned or was entitled to receive but had not yet received at death (e.g., unpaid salary, accrued interest, IRA distributions). It does not receive a stepped-up basis and is taxable when received by the estate or beneficiary.
questions.tip: IRD = earned but not received at death. No step-up, taxable to recipient. Get IRD deduction for estate tax.

questions.question: When a trust distributes income to beneficiaries, the character of the income:

options.A: Becomes ordinary income in all cases
options.B: Retains the same character it had in the trust
options.C: Becomes capital gain in all cases
options.D: Is determined by the beneficiary's tax situation

questions.explanation: Income distributed from a trust retains its character when it flows through to beneficiaries. If the trust received dividend income, the beneficiary reports dividend income. This is similar to partnership character pass-through.
questions.tip: Trust income keeps its character when distributed. Dividends stay dividends, etc.

questions.question: An estate is exempt from paying estimated taxes for:

options.B: The first two tax years after death
options.C: Tax years when the estate has a loss
options.D: Estates with less than $1,000 of income

questions.explanation: Estates are not required to pay estimated taxes for any tax year ending before the date that is 2 years after the decedent's death. After that, normal estimated tax rules apply. Trusts must pay estimated taxes from the start.
questions.tip: Estates: No estimated tax for first 2 years. Trusts: Estimated tax required from year 1.

questions.question: Compared to individual taxpayers, trusts and estates reach the highest marginal tax bracket at:

options.B: Approximately the same income levels
options.C: Much lower income levels
options.D: Trusts are taxed at a flat rate

questions.explanation: Trusts and estates have extremely compressed tax brackets. They reach the 37% bracket at approximately $14,450 of taxable income (2024), compared to over $600,000 for single individuals. This creates incentive to distribute income to beneficiaries.
questions.tip: Trust brackets are compressed. 37% rate hits around $14K. Distribute to avoid high trust taxes!

questions.question: In a complex trust with multiple beneficiaries, distributions of income are allocated to beneficiaries in what order?

options.A: Pro rata based on distributions received
options.B: First tier (required distributions), then second tier (discretionary)
options.C: Based on the trustee's designation

questions.explanation: Complex trusts use a two-tier system: First tier includes required current distributions (taxed to those beneficiaries first, up to their share of DNI). Second tier includes discretionary distributions (share remaining DNI). First tier has priority.
questions.tip: Complex trust tiers: Tier 1 = required distributions (first priority). Tier 2 = discretionary.

questions.question: A trust's charitable deduction for contributions from gross income is:

options.A: Limited to 60% of adjusted gross income
options.B: Limited to 30% of gross income
options.C: Unlimited if paid from gross income pursuant to the governing instrument

questions.explanation: Unlike individuals, trusts and estates can deduct charitable contributions without percentage limitations, provided the contribution is made from gross income and is authorized by the governing instrument. This is a significant tax planning opportunity.
questions.tip: Trust charitable deduction = unlimited (if from income per governing instrument). Better than individual rules!

questions.question: A Section 645 election allows:

options.A: An estate to be treated as a trust
options.B: A qualified revocable trust to be treated as part of the estate
options.C: A trust to avoid filing Form 1041
options.D: Estate income to be taxed to the surviving spouse

questions.explanation: Section 645 allows a qualified revocable trust (one that was treated as a grantor trust before death) to elect to be treated as part of the estate for income tax purposes. This allows fiscal year use and other estate benefits.
questions.tip: Section 645: Revocable trust can join estate for tax purposes. Gets estate benefits.

questions.question: Administration expenses of an estate can be deducted on:

options.B: Form 706 only
options.C: Either Form 1041 or Form 706, but not both

questions.explanation: Administration expenses can be deducted for either income tax purposes (Form 1041) or estate tax purposes (Form 706), but not both. A waiver statement must be filed if claiming the deduction on Form 1041.
questions.tip: Admin expenses: Choose 1041 OR 706, not both. File waiver for income tax deduction.

questions.question: When an estate or trust terminates, excess deductions in the final year:

options.A: Are lost and cannot be used
options.B: Pass through to beneficiaries as itemized deductions
options.C: Carry back to prior estate/trust years

questions.explanation: In the final year, if deductions exceed income, the excess deductions pass through to beneficiaries who can claim them as itemized deductions (miscellaneous itemized deductions not subject to the 2% floor). Unused NOLs and capital loss carryovers also pass through.
questions.tip: Final year: Excess deductions, NOLs, capital losses pass to beneficiaries. Don't waste them!

questions.question: The throwback rules for accumulation distributions apply to:

options.B: Only foreign trusts
options.C: Only domestic trusts

questions.explanation: The throwback rules were repealed for domestic trusts in 1997 but continue to apply to foreign trusts. These rules tax accumulation distributions (distributions exceeding current DNI) as if they had been distributed in prior years when earned.
questions.tip: Throwback rules: Only foreign trusts now. Domestic trusts exempt since 1997.

questions.question: During the grantor's lifetime, a revocable trust is:

options.B: Treated as a grantor trust with income reported by the grantor
options.C: Tax-exempt

questions.explanation: A revocable trust is a grantor trust during the grantor's lifetime because the grantor retains the power to revoke. All income is reported on the grantor's individual return. Upon death, it may become a separate taxpayer or elect Section 645 treatment.
questions.tip: Revocable trust = grantor trust while alive. Power to revoke = grantor trust status.

questions.conceptTested: Election to treat distributions as prior year
questions.question: Under the 65-day rule, a complex trust may elect to treat distributions made within 65 days after year-end as made:

options.B: In the preceding tax year
options.C: Over two tax years equally

questions.explanation: Section 663(b) allows complex trusts and estates to elect to treat distributions made within 65 days after year-end as if made on the last day of the preceding tax year. This provides flexibility in managing DNI and distribution deductions.
questions.tip: 65-day rule: Distributions in first 65 days can be treated as prior year. Great planning tool!

questions.question: A specific bequest of $50,000 cash to a beneficiary is:

options.B: Deductible by the estate
options.C: Not included in DNI and not taxable to the beneficiary

questions.explanation: Specific bequests (specific amounts of money or specific property) paid in three or fewer installments are excluded from DNI and are not taxable to the beneficiary. They are distributions of corpus, not income.
questions.tip: Specific bequests (â‰¤3 installments) = not income to beneficiary. Excluded from DNI.

questions.question: Which power retained by a grantor causes a trust to be a grantor trust?

options.A: Power to remove and replace the trustee with an independent trustee
options.B: Power to distribute income among charitable beneficiaries
options.C: Power to revoke the trust or control beneficial enjoyment
options.D: Power to invade corpus for the health of a beneficiary

questions.explanation: Grantor trust status is triggered when the grantor retains certain powers, including: power to revoke, power to control beneficial enjoyment, certain reversionary interests, power to substitute assets, and certain administrative powers.
questions.tip: Grantor trust triggers: Revoke, control who gets what, reversions >5%, borrow without security, swap assets.

questions.question: A trust has taxable income of $30,000, which includes $5,000 of capital gains allocated to corpus. It also has $4,000 of tax-exempt interest (with $500 allocable expenses). What is DNI?
questions.explanation: DNI = Taxable income ($30,000) - Capital gains allocated to corpus ($5,000) + Tax-exempt interest net of expenses ($4,000 - $500 = $3,500) = $28,500. Capital gains in corpus are excluded; tax-exempt interest is added back.
questions.tip: DNI: Start with TI, subtract corpus capital gains, add back net tax-exempt income.

questions.question: Passive activity losses of a trust are:

options.B: Subject to the same limitations as individuals
options.C: Always passed through to beneficiaries

questions.explanation: Trusts are subject to the same passive activity loss limitations as individuals. Passive losses can only offset passive income and cannot be distributed to beneficiaries. Suspended losses are released when the activity is disposed of.
questions.tip: Trusts: PAL rules apply at trust level. Passive losses don't pass through to beneficiaries.

questions.question: The 3.8% Net Investment Income Tax applies to trusts when undistributed net investment income exceeds:

options.C: The dollar amount at which the highest tax bracket begins

questions.explanation: For trusts and estates, the 3.8% NIIT applies to the lesser of undistributed net investment income or the excess of AGI over the threshold where the highest tax bracket begins (approximately $14,450 for 2024). This is much lower than individual thresholds.
questions.tip: Trust NIIT: Threshold = where 37% bracket starts (~$14K). Much lower than individual $200K-$250K.

questions.question: A qualified disability trust is entitled to:

options.B: A $100 exemption
options.C: A personal exemption equal to that of a single individual

questions.explanation: A qualified disability trust (established for the benefit of a disabled individual under 65) is allowed a personal exemption equal to that available to individual taxpayers, rather than the standard $100 complex trust exemption. This provides significant tax savings.
questions.tip: Qualified disability trust = individual exemption amount. Better than normal $100 complex trust exemption.

questions.question: Under the separate share rule, if a trust has substantially separate shares for different beneficiaries:

options.A: Each share must file a separate return
options.B: DNI is allocated among shares as if each were a separate trust
options.C: All income must be distributed to one beneficiary
options.D: The trust is treated as a simple trust

questions.explanation: The separate share rule treats substantially independent shares of a trust as separate trusts for purposes of computing DNI. This prevents one beneficiary's distribution from carrying out DNI that should be taxable to another beneficiary.
questions.tip: Separate share rule: Each share gets own DNI. Prevents unfair DNI allocation among beneficiaries.

questions.question: A beneficiary who receives income in respect of a decedent (IRD) may be entitled to:

options.A: A deduction for the estate tax attributable to the IRD
options.B: Capital gain treatment on the IRD
options.C: A full exclusion of the IRD from income
options.D: A step-up in basis equal to the IRD

questions.explanation: Section 691(c) allows a deduction for the estate tax paid on IRD items. Since IRD is included in both the estate (for estate tax) and taxable income (to recipient), the deduction mitigates double taxation. It's an itemized deduction not subject to the 2% floor.
questions.tip: IRD deduction: Deduct estate tax paid on IRD. Reduces double taxation on IRD items.

questions.question: A Qualified Subchapter S Trust (QSST) must:

options.A: Distribute all income to multiple beneficiaries
options.B: Have one income beneficiary and distribute all income currently to that beneficiary
options.C: Accumulate income for at least 5 years

questions.explanation: A QSST is permitted to hold S corporation stock. Requirements include: (1) one current income beneficiary, (2) all income must be distributed currently to that beneficiary, (3) corpus distributions can only go to the income beneficiary during their lifetime.
questions.tip: QSST: One beneficiary, all income distributed currently. Can hold S corp stock.

questions.question: Depreciation on trust property must be allocated between the trust and beneficiaries based on:

options.B: Income allocated to each
options.C: Equal shares

questions.explanation: Trust depreciation is allocated between the fiduciary and beneficiaries based on income allocable to each under the trust instrument or local law. If income is distributed, beneficiaries get proportionate depreciation; if retained, the trust claims it.
questions.tip: Trust depreciation follows income. Distributed income = beneficiary's depreciation share.

questions.question: In an Electing Small Business Trust (ESBT), the S corporation portion is taxed at:

options.B: The beneficiaries' rates
options.C: The highest marginal individual rate

questions.explanation: The S corporation portion of an ESBT is taxed as a separate trust and is subject to tax at the highest marginal individual rate (37%). This is different from QSSTs where income flows through to the beneficiary at their rate.
questions.tip: ESBT S corp income = 37% flat rate. Costly but flexible. QSST may be better if one beneficiary.

questions.question: The Section 199A qualified business income deduction for a trust is:

options.B: Calculated at the trust level for retained income only
options.C: Calculated at the trust level and passed through proportionally with QBI
options.D: Always passed through entirely to beneficiaries

questions.explanation: Section 199A applies to trusts. QBI, W-2 wages, and UBIA of qualified property are allocated between the trust and beneficiaries based on the relative portions of DNI allocated to each. Each then calculates their own Section 199A deduction.
questions.tip: Trust QBI: Allocated like other income. Beneficiaries and trust each calculate own 199A deduction.

questions.question: A loss on a sale of property between a trust and its beneficiary is:

options.B: Disallowed under Section 267
options.C: Deductible but only against capital gains
options.D: Deferred until the property is sold to a third party

questions.explanation: Section 267 disallows losses on sales between related parties, including sales between a trust and its beneficiaries. Additionally, gains on such sales may be treated as ordinary income if the property is depreciable to the buyer.
questions.tip: Trust-beneficiary sales: Losses disallowed (Section 267). Gains may be ordinary if depreciable.

questions.question: When a trust terminates and distributes property to beneficiaries, the trust generally recognizes:

options.A: Gain or loss based on FMV
options.B: No gain or loss (carryover basis to beneficiaries)
options.C: Gain only if FMV exceeds basis
options.D: Loss only if basis exceeds FMV

questions.explanation: Generally, when a trust terminates and distributes property in kind, no gain or loss is recognized by the trust, and beneficiaries take a carryover basis. However, the trust can elect to recognize gain or loss and give beneficiaries a FMV basis.
questions.tip: Trust termination: Generally no gain/loss, carryover basis. Can elect gain/loss recognition.
